plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A hardy perennial known for its delicate, white to pale pink flowers that often bloom in winter, sometimes poking through snow. It is native to mountainous regions of Europe and is frequently found in gardens as an early winter bloomer.
plants.location: Europe (Alps, Balkans), cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Despite its name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose but belongs to the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae).

plants.name: Acacia dealbata
plants.description: A fast-growing evergreen tree with feathery, gray-green leaves and bright yellow, fluffy flower clusters that provide vivid color in the winter landscape.
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia, widely cultivated in Mediterranean and mild temperate climates
plants.funFact: Silver Wattle flowers are rich in pollen and nectar, making them important winter food sources for bees and other pollinators.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub prized for its large, rose-like flowers that appear from late autumn through early spring, often blooming around January in mild climates.
plants.location: Native to eastern Asia, extensively cultivated in gardens worldwide, particularly in temperate zones
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers have been cultivated for centuries in East Asia and symbolize admiration and perfection.

plants.name: Eremurus robustus
plants.description: A tall, striking perennial with dense spikes of petite star-shaped flowers, blooming in late winter to early spring in its native mountainous habitats.
plants.location: Central Asia (Tian Shan mountains), grown in temperate botanical gardens
plants.funFact: Foxtail Lilies produce flowering spikes that can reach over 2 meters tall, making them dramatic architectural plants.
